The purpose of DART is to provide just enough kinetic impact (it's traveling about 4.1 miles PER SECOND) so that Dimorphos' orbital period around Didymos is slightly changed, pulling Dimorphos slightly closer to the latter. So it's not just about the impact but other gravitational forces as well. These miniscule shifts provide large magnitudes of course trajectory when you consider the VAST volume of space and distance out there. Think about the impact of a bullet over a mile away by shifting the barrel of a rifle ever so slightly. The results are significant and even more astounding when you're talking about 6.8 million miles ( approximate distance from Earth to Dimorphos at time of impact).
I hope it works. I do. Well just have to wait and see.

11 BILLION pounds. That tiny little speck ain't gonna do anything to Dimorphos. And that's a small asteroid. Just wait for the one they don't see coming that's 10 times it's size. This is like throwing a bb at a freight train traveling 70 miles an hour. Even IF that train weren't on tracks, you aren't budging it off course.

You're acting like this was the movie with Bruce Willis no longer around. It's a test bed to detect minute changes in trajectory due to gravitational shift. We're also talking about 6.8 million miles and a proof-of-concept test bed to gather more data. Stop acting like you know more than the NASA engineers who designed this mission, because you don't.
